Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Primer Generation for Landscape Genetics of Leaf Monkeys and Gibbons in China

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
As habitat loss continues to restrict and fragment dwindling populations of primates, it has become critical to understand the extent to which they are capable of dispersing across different types of geographic boundaries. This NSF research project (EAPSI: Primer Generation for Landscape Genetics of Leaf Monkeys and Gibbons in China) developed novel genetic markers that are being used to study how natural and human-induced environmental variation is affecting endangered primates in China. In particular, I am studying how differences in primate locomotion and social structure affect the ability of black crested gibbons and Phayre's leaf monkeys to exchange genes across geographic boundaries. To understand this relationship, I am measuring the amount of gene flow between groups of primates throughout a geographically variable region of China. This entails extracting DNA from many individuals and comparing how closely related they are by looking for differences in small fragments of their DNA, which are called, "markers." When researching understudied, rare species it is often the case that no genetic markers are known; in order to study them, we have to find the markers from scratch. I was looking for a type of genetic marker called a, "microsatellite." Microsatellites are small stretches of DNA in every individual that repeat a short sequence a variable number of times (e.g. ACACACAC or ACACAC). By identifying which individuals share which microsatellite variations, I can determine how recently they exchanged genes, which will allow me to know if gene flow is blocked by a geographic boundary in one or both species. This research will provide a new understanding of how habitat changes affect the long-term health of endangered primates, which will have a profound affect on our ability to conserve them.

 

Because of the rapid rate of development, habitat loss, and the number of at-risk primates, China is an ideal location to examine this relationship. Through the NSF EAPSI program, I was able to work with Dr. Jiang Xuelong and Dr. Douglas Yu at the Kunming Institute of Zoology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Yunnan province, while establishing a formal, long term collaboration for my research project. During the summer of 2010, we used next-generation DNA sequencing technology on two samples of tissue form the species of interst. This allowed us to identify tens of thousands of random fragments of DNA for both primate species. By looking for repeated bits of DNA sequence with a specialized computer program, we were able to determine that over 3,000 of the randomly generated fragments contained microsatellites. About 10-15% of these contained flanking regions called, "primers" that would be suitable for use in the laboratory. For the past several months, we have been finalizing these results and will publish them in peer reviewed academic journals. Currently we are continuing to use these markers to identify the pattern of gene flow among black-crested gibbons and Phayre's leaf monkeys in Yunnan province. This long-term research project will continue for the foreseeable future, and was critically supported in its early stages by the NSF EAPSI program.
